abstract: <jats:p>The analyses of genetic interaction between maternal and offspring genotypes are usually conducted considering a single locus. Here, we propose testing maternal × offspring (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">O</jats:styled-content>) and maternal × maternal (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>) genotype interactions involving two unlinked loci. We reformulate the log‐linear approach of analyzing cases and their parents (family trios) to accommodate two loci, fit fuller models to avoid confounding in a first analysis step and propose that the model be reduced to the most prominent effects in a second step. We conduct extensive simulations to assess the validity and power of this approach under various model assumptions. We show that the approach is valid and has good power to detect <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">O</jats:styled-content> and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content> interactions. For example, the power to detect a dominant interaction relative risk of 1.5 (both <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">O</jats:styled-content> and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>) is 70% with 300 trios and approaches 100% with 1,000 trios. Unlike the main effects, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">O</jats:styled-content> and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content> interactions are conditionally independent of mating types, and consequently, their power is not affected by missing paternal genotypes. When applied to single‐locus <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">O</jats:styled-content> interaction, our method is as powerful as other existing methods. Applying the method to testicular cancer, we found a nominally significant <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>×<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content> interaction between single nucleotide polymorphisms from <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>‐<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">K</jats:styled-content>it <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">L</jats:styled-content>igand (<jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">KITLG</jats:styled-content></jats:italic>) and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>ex <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>ormone <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>inding <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>lobulin (<jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SHBG</jats:styled-content></jats:italic>) using 210 families (relative risk 2.2, <jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 0.03). This finding supports a role of maternal hormones in offspring testicular cancer and warrants confirmation in a larger dataset.</jats:p>
